> > I suppose that contract could be:
> >
> > 0 <= newCollection.size - oldCollection.size <= 1
> >
>
>  From what I understand of DBC, I'm not sure that this would be a
> precise enough contract.  I think I could pretty easily write a bad
> implementation that always meets the contract: never add the object to
> the container, so new.size()-old.size() always equals 0.

My understanding of DBC is that the contracts' primary purpose is to prevent
a) clients from invoking servers in a way the server code cannot handle:
precoditions
b) servers from implementing (polymorphic) functions in a way the client
does not expect: postconditions and invariants

IMO it is *not* a primary purpose of DBC to verify the correctness of
implementation. In that respect DBC differs from code verification
techniques (CVT). Code verification requires very detailed specification. In
fact, this specification is usually at least as complex as the code itself
and often more complex when you have to specify eg. concurrent behaviour.
It's no coincidence that CVT is only rarely used in real world projects,
mostly telecom and medical applications. There's a tremendous amount of
theory behind CVTs of which Mr. Meyer surely was aware when suggesting a
simpler and pragmatic way to specify "contracts" between "components".

Disclaimer: It's been a while that I've read Meyer's book on DBC, but I have
taken part in projects trying to adopt DBC since.
